newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine lower house approves 1997 budget plan.
newsitem.headline: Argentine lower house approves 1997 budget plan.

text.p: The lower house of the Argentine Congress gave general approval late on Wednesday to a 1997 budget plan providing for a deficit of about $3.2 billion.

Deputies must now debate the plan item by item and make changes. The final proposal is still expected to exceed the deficit of $3 billion, equivalent to one percent of gross domestic product, agreed with International Monetary Fund.
Congressmen added expenditures of more than $400 million to the government's budget bill, pushing the 1997 deficit to about $3.485 billion.
But they included an article allowing the government to slash $285 million off spending at its own discretion to bring it down to about $3.2 billion.

The 1997 budget bill forecasts 1997 GDP growth of five percent, consumption growth of 4.3 percent and real investment growth of 10 percent. It also foresees a trade deficit of about $2.0 billion on exports of $27.5 billion and imports of $29.5 billion.
After the lower house passes the package on a line-by-line basis, it must receive Senate approval.
